title: 113_hr1477
content: The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new subpart called the Holocaust Education Assistance Program, also known as the Simon Wiesenthal Holocaust Education Assistance Act. This subpart aims to provide assistance for Holocaust education. Congress finds that the Holocaust resulted in the mass murders of 6,000,000 Jews by Nazi Germany. Some states mandate Holocaust education in schools, while others recommend it but lack funding. Teaching the Holocaust is challenging and requires appropriate resources for educators. The purpose of this subpart is to educate students in the United States about the lessons of the Holocaust, combat Holocaust denial, and provide resources for accurate historical information and community sensitization. The purpose of this subpart is to educate students in the United States about the lessons of the Holocaust, combat denial, and provide resources for historical information and community sensitization. It aims to convey the lessons of the Holocaust and develop curriculum guides for teachers to incorporate its study into mainstream disciplines. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to educational organizations for Holocaust educational programs. Grants can only be awarded to organizations that submit an application containing required information. An educational organization receiving a grant under this subpart must use the grant solely for the Holocaust education program it was provided for. The organization must continue to be eligible and ensure the grant supplements, not replaces, non-Federal funds for the program. Additional conditions may be imposed by the Secretary. The Secretary may impose additional terms and conditions for grants under this subpart. Educational organizations are encouraged to collaborate with state or local educational agencies when applying for and using grants. The Secretary will award grants based on competitive criteria established in consultation with Holocaust educators. Additionally, there will be a review process and potential sanctions in place. The Secretary will conduct annual reviews of educational organizations receiving grants to ensure compliance with regulations. Sanctions may be imposed for non-compliance. A report on activities under this subpart will be submitted to Congress annually. An educational organization is defined as a tax-exempt entity organized for cultural, literary, or educational purposes. A Holocaust education program aims to raise awareness of the Holocaust through educational materials and activities. The term 'Holocaust' refers to the mass murders by Nazi Germany of 6,000,000 Jews and others in the name of racial purity. Educational activities, teacher training, and other services are aimed at improving awareness and understanding of the Holocaust. The Secretary will issue regulations for the Holocaust Education Assistance Program. $2,000,000 is authorized for grants annually for five years. A clerical amendment adds the program to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Holocaust Education Assistance Program includes sections on short title, findings and purposes, program authorization, application, use of grants, selection criteria, review and sanctions, annual report, definitions, regulations, and authorization of appropriations.
